column2: Professional Development provided for Teachers\r\rMeasure2017-182018-192019-20\rNumber of school days dedicated to Staff Development and Continuous Improvement33\r\rLearningSupportServicesDepartmentprovidednumerousopportunitiesforprofessionaldevelopmentthroughoutthe2018-19schoolyear.\rKindergarten through sixth grade teachers participated in monthly District-wide Collaboration Meetings  to address key areas identified in the District-\rwide Professional Development Plan. Topics included: Common Core implementation and strategies to meet the rigors demanded in the new standards
column8: and\rUsing Technology in the Classroom. Each school identified areas based on student achievement data and focused teacher professional development in\rproviding effective quality-first instruction in these key areas.\r\rHillcrest was engaged in the following professional development activities during the 2018-19 school year: Book studies included:  -- Balanced Literacy\rand Literacy centers for grades K - 6th grades; Blooms Taxonomy of Higher Level Thinking Skills; Web's Depth of Knowledge strategies; Project Based\rLearning (PBL) for upper grades; Development of collaborative standards-based lesson plans emphasizing measurable
column9: targeted and student friendly\rlearning objectives in Professional Learning Communities (PLC) that included Specific
column12: Realistic and Timely (SMART) goals;\rCollaborative development and implementation of English Language Arts Curriculum Guide for all grade levels; District Benchmark assessment data\rreview
column13: formative assessment analysis was conducted on a regular basis for instructional decisions to improve quality-first instruction to improve student\racademic performance.  Continued training with the English Language Arts adoption for all teachers was conducted.  An English Language Learner\rInterventionist provided direct instruction for long-term English Learners that is "above and beyond' the core classroom ELD instruction. Teachers and\rpara-professionals are trained in the administration of an effective Response to Instruction and Intervention (RtII) for non-proficient students. The School\rLeadership Team
column14: grade level and full staff meetings were devoted to improving PLC work. Teachers were trained in methods to share instruction
column15: \rcurricular services and assessment information with parents during School Advisory Committee
column17: School Site\rCouncil meetings. Training of parent/community members with appropriate advisory input for the development and monitoring of the School Plan for\rStudent Achievement (SPSA) was provided. Garvey School District's Teachers on Special Assignment conducted regularly scheduled teacher trainings\rfocusing on: lesson development and lesson delivery
column19: Close Reading strategy to help student gain greater access to the\rCommon Core Standards coupled with reflective feedback among classroom teachers.\r\rGarvey District is committed to providing high quality professional learning for administrators
column21: classified staff and parents that is aligned to the\rDistrict's Mission and Vision.  District teachers and support staff participate in Professional Development Days that are driven by student achievement\rdata
column22: staff learning needs and research-based best practices.  Four District-wide days of professional learning and collaboration for 2018-2019 are\rconcentrated around our academic and whole-child focus areas with an emphasis on English Learners
column24: and Low-Income Pupils.  These focus\rareas are in direct alignment with federal
column26: and district student achievement academic goals.  Additionally
column27: the drive effective instructional\rintervention to promote students' academic growth.  Each site's professional development plan is designed collaboratively to address identified student\rachievement and staff needs that are aligned to the District's focus areas as indicated in each site's School Plan for Student Achievement (SPSA).  The\rDistrict's Teachers on Special Assignment (TOSAs) facilitate trainings
column29: and conduct sessions on lesson design and delivery of District\rfocus areas
column30: and other site and District instructional initiatives.  A team of TOSAs and veteran teachers serve as the District's teacher support program\rmentors for Garvey's Teacher Induction Program for participating teachers in the process of clearing their credential.  These programs support the\rtraining
column32: and retention of high quality teachers using current research on effective teaching and grounds what they are learning in daily\rpractices.  Garvey administrators
